bestBHT.bht: The tribute mentioned in this context was a poll-tax imposed on Judaea by Rome. The people questioning Jesus had their own hidden motives - if he said yes, they could accuse him of supporting Roman rule, but if he said no, they could accuse him to the Roman authorities. Their true intent stemmed from their hatred of Jesus, which is further evidenced by their later accusation that he forbade tribute payment. Jesus was caught in a difficult situation, as his response could have consequences both among the people and with the Roman governor.

Henry Alford: 17.] The tribute here spoken of was a poll-tax, which had been levied since Judæa became a province of Rome.
Philip Schaff: To say Yes, would alienate the people, who hated the Roman yoke; to say No, would have given good ground for accusing Him to the Roman authorities.
Their motive now was not their usual hostility to Rome, but hatred of Christ.

They afterwards actually accused Him of forbidding to pay tribute (Luke 23:2), and the chief priests, despite their Pharisaism, from the same hatred of Him, cried out: ‘We have no king but Cesar’ (John 19:15).
John Gill: Whether is it lawful to give tribute unto Caesar, or not? Meaning, according to the law of God.
Had he said that it was lawful to give tribute to Caesar, this being contrary to the general notions of the people, they would have improved it to draw them from him, and to set them against him.

Had he affirmed it was not lawful to do it, they would then have accused him to the Roman governor, and delivered him up into his hands, to judge and condemn him, according to the Roman laws; which latter was what they were wishing for.
John Wesley: Is it lawful to give tribute to Cesar?" — If he had said, Yes, the Pharisees would have accused him to the people, as a betrayer of the liberties of his country.
If he had said, No, the Herodians would have accused him to the Roman governor.

bhtAttempts.bht: The tribute mentioned in this verse refers to a poll-tax that was imposed on Judaea by Rome. The people who questioned Jesus had ulterior motives - if he said yes, they could accuse him of being in favor of the Roman yoke, but if he said no, they could accuse him to the Roman authorities. Their true intent was rooted in their hatred of Jesus, as seen when they later accused him of forbidding tribute payment and declared, We have no king but Caesar. Jesus was caught in a difficult position, as his response would have consequences both in the eyes of the people and the Roman governor.

The tribute mentioned in this particular context was a poll-tax imposed on the province of Judaea by Rome. The people who questioned Jesus had their own motives - if he said yes, they could accuse him of betraying his country, and if he said no, they could accuse him to the Roman governor. However, their true intent was rooted in their hatred for Jesus. Jesus found himself in a difficult position, as his response could have negative consequences in the eyes of both the people and the Roman authorities.

The tribute mentioned in this context was a poll-tax imposed on Judaea by Rome. The people questioning Jesus had their own hidden motives - if he said yes, they could accuse him of supporting Roman rule, but if he said no, they could accuse him to the Roman authorities. Their true intent stemmed from their hatred of Jesus, which is further evidenced by their later accusation that he forbade tribute payment. Jesus was caught in a difficult situation, as his response could have consequences both among the people and with the Roman governor.

The tribute mentioned here pertains to the poll-tax imposed on Judaea by Rome. The interrogators had ulterior motives - if Jesus agreed, they could accuse him of supporting Roman oppression, but if he disagreed, they could accuse him to the Roman authorities. Their underlying intent stemmed from their deep animosity towards Jesus, as later revealed when they accused him of forbidding tribute payment. Jesus found himself in a dilemma, knowing that any response could have unfavorable consequences amidst the people and the Roman governor.

The tribute mentioned in this context refers to a poll-tax imposed on Judaea by Rome. The interrogators had hidden motives: if Jesus affirmed it, they could accuse him of siding with the Roman authorities, but if he denied it, they could report him to the Roman governor. Their true intention arose from their deep-seated malice towards Jesus, as evidenced by their later accusation that he prohibited tribute payment. Jesus was confronted with a difficult decision, aware that any response could have negative repercussions among the people and the Roman authorities.
